key_findings: AmbiK dataset provides 1000 pairs of ambiguous and unambiguous kitchen robot instructions, totaling 2000 tasks, addressing the lack of standardized benchmarks for ambiguity detection in embodied AI systems.
The dataset categorizes ambiguity into three distinct types: Human Preferences, Common Sense Knowledge, and Safety, enabling systematic evaluation of different ambiguity detection approaches.
LLM-assisted data collection combined with human validation creates a scalable methodology for generating high-quality ambiguous instruction datasets in domain-specific environments.
Each task pair includes comprehensive annotations: environment descriptions, clarifying questions and answers, user intents, and task plans, providing rich context for training and evaluation.
The fully textual nature of the dataset makes it accessible for researchers without requiring complex robotic simulation environments, lowering barriers to entry for ambiguity detection research.
limitations: Dataset is limited to kitchen environment scenarios, potentially limiting generalizability to other domains
Reliance on LLM-assisted generation may introduce biases inherent in the underlying language models used for data creation
future_work: Extension to other domestic and industrial environments beyond kitchen settings
problem_addressed: Lack of standardized benchmark for evaluating ambiguity detection methods in embodied AI systems, particularly for natural language instruction interpretation in robotic environments
prerequisites: Access to LLMs for data generation
real_world_applications: Natural language interface for robotic systems
